body:
I don't see any producer config or security here?
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/System+Tools#SystemTools-GetOffsetShell

In general, we are keeping the old producer in console-producer and mirrormaker because those tools "produce", and users may care about how they produce.

GetOffsetShell doesn't produce, it just uses a method that was conveniently available in the producer and someone didn't take good care in encapsulation and dependencies when writing this tool.

Ideally, we will refactor getTopicMetadata in the new clients (or into common, most likely) so this tool will not depend on a producer at all.

@granders up for your review again. Some of the issues you have seen in past might be due to ReplicaVerificationTool not getting killed properly in previous runs. Fixed that and ran a few times in loop. Hopefully it checks out at your end as well.

The build failure is unrelated. Below is the cause, which seems new to me. Should this be a new JIRA? Not sure if there is already a JIRA tracking this issue.

```
pure virtual method called
terminate called without an active exception
:streams:test FAILED
```
Yes, please file a new JIRA.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.
One general comment: it is probably better to move the StreamPartitioner parameter before the topic String in all the functions.

> One general comment: it is probably better to move the StreamPartitioner parameter before the topic String in all the functions.

Sure. Can you explain why this is better?
@gwenshap System tests passed 160/161, and the failure looks unrelated. Care to merge?
I updated the PR title.
Since all the parameters except String topic name is nullable, and overloaded w/o.
LGTM
Could you also run the system tests on this patch?
Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3508 for unit test failure.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.
LGTM
@junrao This doesn't merge cleanly anymore after https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/b94a7812beeb840926871df84838f35ca7b76ffe
@guozhangwang, can you please review this if you have time?
@guozhangwang Just updated this.

The Jenkins failure is unrelated to this PR (it passed locally too):

```
pthread lock: Invalid argument
:streams:test FAILED
```
Quick note to mention that the PR does not merge cleanly to trunk at the moment.
Started a system tests build here: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/405/
@ijuma @ewencp I made the retries configurable and set it to Int.MaxValue in the tests. Do you think this needs a KIP since its a "public" config? Or is it small enough to skip?

@ijuma I could definitely do that. I chose to expose it as a public configuration because I was already on edge about exposing it and this test failure helped show that a user may want to have a higher value too. Especially because my initial implementation was unlimited. Often I find that if something needs to be exposed in tests its likely its useful to expose it for general use too.
@granthenke I'm not sure, it seems unlikely that users would be adding ACLs with a large number of threads simultaneously. I think a config like this would require a KIP indeed.

@ijuma I agree it may not be common. But that situation is why max retries was suggested and added. Its also why the test exists. Its threads in the test case, but its individual users or applications in real usage. In the case it is an issue it would be nice for a user to be able to resolve it. 

I am weighing that against the potential "harm" having a public config could have and it feels like adding a config is simple and has very little downside. Are there any major drawbacks you see to having a configuration?
@ijuma @granthenke I don't think we should necessarily expose the config to users per se, I'd treat it as public for testing only (and comment appropriately).
@ewencp Are you suggesting using the protected variable like @ijuma suggested? Or leaving the config property but documenting it?
One minor feedback about WindowedStreamPartitioner in comments, otherwise LGTM.
Thanks for the updates @SinghAsDev - only a couple minor comments
@ijuma have you seen this before? `kafka.server.LogRecoveryTest.testHWCheckpointWithFailuresSingleLogSegment`

LGTM except the failure above. Re-running the unit test locally now.

Don't know why github diff file was messed with simple renaming changes, which make the reviewing harder though.
These tickets are closed and hence cannot re-open, could you create a new one and link to them?
Thanks for you comment @guozhangwang! Updated this again if you want we to squash the commits just let me know.
Local unit test passed. Merged to trunk.
The merge script squashes the commits. The main thing to know is that the PR title and description are used in the squashed commit.
My take is that public for testing is sometimes unavoidable in Java, but is generally avoidable in Scala due to its support for richer access control modifiers.
@ijuma You mean, it does not matter what I put into the single commit comments and the PR title and description from Git are used?
@ijuma @ewencp I changed the patch to use a protected variable

@mjsax Yes, it does not matter what you write in the individual commits when it comes to what gets merged. However, the individual commits can still be helpful when people review the pull request. In terms of what gets merged, all that matters is the pull request title and description. The merge script will use those in the squashed commit message.

@guozhangwang Looking at the failure, it seems like it was due to a timeout. Given the fact that there were 2 other failures in that build, I think Jenkins was probably overloaded. Do you still think we should file a JIRA for testHWCheckpointWithFailuresSingleLogSegment or shall we first check if it happens again?
Thanks @granthenke, LGTM.

@mjsax There seems some uncleaned imports from your last commit:

```
:streams:checkstyleMain[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KStream.java:23:8: Unused import - org.apache.kafka.streams.kstream.internals.WindowedSerializer.
[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KTable.java:23:8: Unused import - org.apache.kafka.streams.kstream.internals.WindowedSerializer.
```

@mjsax There seems some uncleaned imports from your last commit:

```
:streams:checkstyleMain[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KStream.java:23:8: Unused import - org.apache.kafka.streams.kstream.internals.WindowedSerializer.
[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KTable.java:23:8: Unused import - org.apache.kafka.streams.kstream.internals.WindowedSerializer.
```
Let's wait until we see another case of this failure then.

@guozhangwang I am too used to Flink (build fails there if unused imports are detected). Btw: the import is not really unused; but only needed for JavaDoc. Thus, IntelliJ does not mark them as an unused import...

Anyway. I fixed it.
I just pushed but it does not show up... Not sure why...
@mjsax You can use `./gradlew checkstyleMain checkstyleTest` to trigger checkstyle. I do see your latest commit.
The latest IntelliJ 2016.1 EAP fixes this issue: https://confluence.jetbrains.com/display/IDEADEV/IntelliJ+IDEA+2016.1+145.844.1+Release+Notes
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
LGTM too. Sorry this seemingly trivial patch resulted in so much discussion @granthenke :/
ping @apovzner @enothereska for reviews.
Unit test passed locally. LGTM and merged to trunk.
+1. minor
Ping @ewencp for reviews.

@guozhangwang Besides comment left inline, I think you can remove the dependency on `connect:json` in `build.gradle:712` since that was only there for serializers as far as I can tell.

Rest of the code looks good to me. You could also avoid the code duplication between clients and connect by just moving all the code and leaving the connect version inheriting from the clients class (but still marked deprecated), but this code is small and simple enough that I am not particularly concerned about that.

Discussed with @ewencp offline, and we decided to postpone this movement until we break `kafka-clients` into separate jars.

And I'm assuming @ijuma will drive the split :100:
Any news on this PR? If there is something else to do, I can work on this.
@guozhangwang :)
@miguno @guozhangwang please have a look when you can. Thanks.
ping @guozhangwang please have a look if you can.

A general question: do we need to let print / write return the same object of KStream / KTable as well? For programmability, would users feel it more intuitive as:

```
stream1 = source.map(...).filter(...);
stream1.print();   // this is for debugging, deleted before moving to productiong

stream2 = stream1.transform(...);
stream2.print();   // this is for debugging, deleted before moving to productiong
```

Or

```
source.map(...).filter(...);
          .print();   // this is for debugging, deleted before moving to productiong
          .transform(...);
          .print();   // this is for debugging, deleted before moving to productiong
```
Could we add a `foreach` operation to KTable as well?
@ijuma @junrao Thank you for the review. I have done the rebase and started a system test run.
unit test passed locally.
@guozhangwang i can add to KTable as well as part of same PR.
I ran with my use-case that used to fail consistently when calling forward() from punctuate, and now it works. LGTM based on that.
Inviting @norwood to review as well.

since streams is already depending on slf4j whats the motivation behind not just using slf4j for output instead of manually handling `System.out` and other `PrintStream`s.

you could have something like 

```
KStream<K, V> print(String name);
```

and then use that named logger to print that stream. this also allow you to externally config printing on/off so you don't even need to remove the `.print()` calls for production if you dont want to.

edit: this would also allow us to get rid of the `writeAsText` methods
@granders I agree with your comment about self.prop_file. I updated the PR such that verifiable producer now has prop_file method. This is consistent with ConsoleConsumer behavior.
This seems fine to me, let's see what @junrao says.

Ping @enothereska for reviews.

Also added error messages in UnsupportedExceptions in StandbyContextImpl as part of this PR.

System tests passed.

@ewencp, it would also be good for you to take a look as I assume you'll be the committer reviewing this. Some context: Geoff did most of the work on this branch before 0.9.0.0 went out. I needed this functionality, so Geoff rebased the branch and I tested it and added minor fixes and improvements.

System test results are here: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/406/. There was one failure (OffsetValidationTest) which is an existing transient failure already being addressed by KAFKA-3513.

@hachikuji I have updated the PR with the fix you suggested to fail requests only on expiry. I used session timeout rather than request timeout as expiry, but will be happy to change it to request timeout if that is more appropriate. Can you take a look? Thank you.
On second thought, request timeout looks better as expiry timeout since session timeout can be quite large. Have updated the PR.
Unit test passed locally.
@ijuma Other than fixing the conditional in `producer_performance.py` this looks good to me. Let's see if @ewencp has further comments

@rajinisivaram LGTM. I ran all the client system tests to be sure there weren't any obvious problems. One minor note: there's a TODO at the top of ConsumerNetworkClient that I think we can get rid of now. 

I'll ask @ewencp if he has time to review since he's also worked in this code quite a bit.

@ewencp I turned off stdout collection since I can probably get by with the event logging itself. Note that we may may have to turn down that logging (or at least choose the events we log more selectively) if VerifiableConsumer ever does log messages individually. This change results in about 5-10 Mb increase in overall retained data.

@hachikuji Why not collect it in just the one test you care about as I suggested? If you need the info, I don't have a problem collecting it, I just thought it made sense to limit extra collection of data to the specific test we need it for.

I think the confusion re: verbosity came up because I know we have a verbose mode in VerifiableConsumer, but I guess we never enable it in the system tests...

@ewencp I care about one test at the moment, but I'm assuming that others may also have transient failures in the future. The problem is that these failures tend to be hard to reproduce (e.g. I still haven't reproduced the one in 3513 yet), so I need to get as much information from each failure as possible.
@hachikuji Thank you for the review and for running the system tests. I have removed the TODO in ConsumerNetworkClient.

Couple notes on the current patch:
1. I have not implemented the 'forward' flag as documented on the KIP. The purpose of the flag was to detect when a request loop had been encountered in the restart forwarding. I discussed the problem with @Ishiihara and we feel this scenario is unlikely to be a problem in practice since it requires consecutive rebalances at a very quick rate. We can imagine a request getting "unlucky" once if a rebalance is triggered just after forwarding, but it's hard to imagine multiple times. And if we are not concerned about the degenerate case, then this actually gives the request some fault tolerance since we would otherwise have to surface the routing failure to the user. On the other hand, if we think this is a serious problem, then it would make more sense to have a general solution which can also be applied to requests which are only forwarded to the leader.
2. The KIP documented returning 409 when there is a conflicting operation in progress (such as another restart or a rebalance). This is actually trickier than it sounds since the rebalance is hidden inside WorkerCoordinator.poll(). We could set a flag in the revocation callback to indicate that the rebalance has begun, but the rebalance might begin immediately after checking it, so there would be no guarantee that the restart _didn't_ get stuck behind a rebalance. For a restart, we would need to track some additional state for each task and we would need the ability to inspect the request queue in `DistributedHerder` to see if there were any pending restarts for the same task. This is doable, but the cost feels quite high for a questionable capability since the only impact of not having it is that concurrent restart requests may cause unneeded restarts. However, if restarting is expensive for some connectors, maybe it does have some value.
LGTM, thanks @rajinisivaram!

@granders Thanks a lot for your comments. I addressed them. And also want to sneak in one more fix in verifiable producer that I found when writing new tests -- each_produced_at_least() uses range incorrectly, the last param is up to, not including; that's a recently added method; I verified that both tests that use it are passing.

@granders I changed the handling of compression types as you suggested. I agree that's a better way, and more straightforward. I verified that all tests are using compression types this way -- either None or list of compression types, one per each producer.

@apovzner Great, thanks a lotfor the updates, this looks good to me
@ewencp Mind taking a final look?

This patch moves the onJoinComplete() call into the callback for the join group. This ensures that we'll eventually call it even if we break from the rebalance due to a wakeup. This seems to work nicely with the check for pending requests to the coordinator which we use prior to sending a new join group, but let me know if I missed something.
Note we also change the semantics of using event time for punctuate instead of wall clock time. I think this is the right modification, especially for future emitting policies and session window.
@guozhangwang It looks like you may have forgotten to check in `MockProcessorNode`?
LGTM
@ewencp Ouch, thanks.
I added a sample of the generated docs to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3480, both as a html file as well as a screenshot.

@guozhangwang - 
       -      Changed print and writeAsText method return signature to void 
       -       Flush System.out on close, 
       -       Changed IllegalStateException to TopologyBuilderException, 
       -       Updated JavaDoc stating need to override toString, 

@norwood 
       -  Renamed KStreamPrinter to KeyValuePrinter
       -  Updated the printing of null keys to 'null' to match ConsoleConsumer
